explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) applicability in the Fehmarn Belt – This area is governed by structured routing measures for vessels transiting between the North Sea and Baltic Sea, particularly near the Femern Fixed Link Holding Area North, where linear navigation is mandated to avoid conflicts in high-density maritime corridors.
Operational Protocol Rationale: Cargo vessels of standard dimensions operating without hazardous cargo typically follow fixed, straight routes in this region after completing navigational turns, as seen when transitioning from a curved approach into a stabilized east-southeast heading. The consistent speed, minimal heading variation, and alignment between course over ground and heading indicate autopilot-assisted, rule-compliant passage through a designated shipping lane. This behavior is favored over more dynamic maneuvers—such as anchoring, drifting, or sharp turning—due to the constraints imposed by nearby protected areas, wind farms, and regulated holding zones, all of which necessitate predictable, linear motion once alignment with the transit corridor is achieved.
